editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:

All honour then and glory be (as it is worthy) yeelded vnto him, who lea≈øt we walking in darkenes know not whither to goe, hath prouided vs a Candell of his holy doctrine euen in the midde≈øt of Egypt, and ≈øet it vpon a candle≈øticke in the Catholicke Church: where tho≈øe which are out of this hou≈øe of God liuing in palpable darkenes; the children of this light may ≈øafely expecte the ri≈øing of that ≈øtarre, wc neuer ≈øhall ≈øette, which is the cleare vi≈øion of Gods euerla≈øting glory. This light although by diuer≈øe per≈øons who loue darkenes better than light, it hath by ≈øundry meanes bene a≈ø≈øaulted: yet hath the≈øe a≈ø≈øaultes done nothing e ‚Ä¢ ≈øe, but by encrea≈øing the aduer≈øe darkenes, made the light appeare more gloriou≈øe: and contrary to mans expectation, yet agreeably to Gods di≈øpo≈øition, not brought water to quench, but fewell to feede ≈øo liuely ≈ølames. Hence may we in all places of our Countrey to our owne great comforte, and Gods ≈øingular glory, out of Pri≈øons, out of Iudgementes, out of all maner of publicke places, out of many priuate
per≈øons and families, behold the beames of this light ≈øo vehemently i≈ø≈øuing forth;Mat. 24, 27. that comming out of the Ea≈øt (for to v≈øe our Sauiours wordes) it appeareth euen to the We≈øt: and it ≈øhineth ≈øo generally abroade, that it is renowmed in the wholle world: which ≈øeeing the beauty thereof, glorifieth our Father of light which is in heauen.

Onely (my deare Catholicke Brother) who being vnlearned ≈øeeke≈øt to treade the ≈øteppes of thy forefathers, & walking in darkenes of this mortall life, procure≈øt to follow tho≈øe which bef ‚Ä¢ re thee haue caried lightes for thy direction: it ≈øometime cometh into my minde to feare, lea≈øt either thy torchbearers being taken from thee, or for ouer-long watching, the oile of the Lampe which they may leaue thee (I meane charitie and a good con≈øcience1. Tim. 1, 19. the tinder and fewell of that light of Faith) begining to faile; the light it ≈øelfe may by little and little be extingui≈øhed: and ≈øo thou returning to thy former darkene≈ø≈øe, togither with the children of darkenes, maie≈øt fall and peri≈øhe. We are not ignorant of his cogitations, who like a roaring Lion goeth about ≈øeeking whom he may deuour: and among≈øt other ≈øleightes which he v≈øeth, transfiguring him≈øelfe into an Angell of light, with a counterfaite light of hypocri≈øy and here≈øy; ≈øeeketh to depriue thee of that which is true and ≈øincere.

Wherefore I offer vnto thee a torch or candell, containing in it, although in a ≈ømall match, the wh ‚Ä¢ ll lighte of Chri≈øtian Rel ‚Ä¢ gion, which although it bee lighted at the candel of another man: yet thou knowe≈øt, that light is neuer the le≈ø≈øe becau≈øe it is receiued of another: and in this it is more free from all ≈øu≈øpition, whereas it is the ≈øame light which lighteneth many
other partes of the world. This when thou ha≈øt once receiued, and fully enioied, thy ≈øelfe: thinke that thou ha≈øt not performed thy duety, if thou imparte it not to thy children. O how they are deceiued, & in how great daunger of euerla≈øting damnation doe they liue, who as though they had by carnall generatioÃÑ brought into this world brute bea≈øtes, who≈øe onely end is to liue here, without any end of heauenly bli≈ø≈øe: do not ≈øeeke for their children the meanes of their ≈øaluation, onely prouiding for them earthly riches, not caring for heauenly. Nor con≈øidering, that be≈øides the very bonde of the lawe of nature, & of God him≈øelfe, who hath giuen mo≈øt ≈øtraite charge of good education of children: Chri≈øt our Sauiour hath con≈øecrated Chri≈øtian mariages into a ≈øacrament, for this end among≈øt others; that they may pre≈øent vnto our Sauiour ≈øanctified children by bapti≈øme fir≈øt, and afterward by all Chri≈øtian and Catholike di≈øcipline. The Turke or Iew if he ≈øhould perceiue his child to haue bene pre≈øent at Chri≈øtian Ceremonies, would not ≈øticke to embrew his handes in that which he begotte. And yet he wc profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe a Catholicke, by ≈øending his child, or permitting his childe to be ≈øent to ≈øuch thinges as are indi≈øpen≈øably forbidden by God him≈øelfe: doth vnnaturally depriue his innocent ≈øonne of that which he coulde not giue him. But to the intent that thou maie≈øt not onely performe this duety, which is nece≈ø≈øarily & vpon paine of vtter darkenes required of thee: but al≈øo like vnto a childe of lighte ≈øeeke that which is perfect, and according to the nature of light liberally endeuour to communicate vnto al meÃÑ that which thou ha≈øt thy ≈øelfe of God receiued: I haue ≈øet downe in the margen of this booke, all tho≈øe places of holy Fathers and Scriptures which are in the Lattin: to the intent that thou either being a≈ø≈øaulted by any aduer≈øary, or thy ≈øelfe ≈øeeking to re≈øchew out of mi≈øerable captiuitie any ≈øoule: maie≈øt haue authorities to alleage for what≈øoeuer thou ≈øhalt ≈øay. Of the places of ≈øcripture for the mo≈øt parte I haue quoted the very ver≈øe‚ñ™ that ≈øodainely thou maie≈øt find that wherin con≈øi≈øteth the force of the proofe.

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.
div.p: VVHereas there is promi≈øed thee about the latter end of the booke a Treati≈øe of ≈øeruice and ≈øcripture in the vulgar tongue: know thou that by rea≈øon of the continuall warres in this Countrey and the manifolde difficulties which all tho≈øe that liue here-about doe feele: I haue bene con≈øtrained to fini≈øh this worke, without ful accompli≈øhment of my promi≈øe and purpo≈øe. But thou in the meane time enioy this my pre≈øent which I make thee: & if I ≈øhall perceiue that this my labour is grateful vnto thee: then ≈øhalt thou in the next edition receiue a perfect recompence for this my defaulte. I haue al≈øo ≈øet down a Catalogue of the Fathers and Doctours wc are in this Booke alleaged, that thou maie≈øt ≈øee how auncient defendours we haue of the Catholike truth: which in deede neither could be Catholicke if it had not antiquitie with it: neither can want antiquitie if it be Catholicke. So that in my iudgement two principall thinges thou ≈øhalt finde in this Booke, of them≈øelues ≈øufficient to confirme thy owne Faith, and to confound the negatiue Religion of al aduer≈øaries. The fir≈øt is the very naked & ≈øincere truth very plainly & expre≈øly ≈øet downe. The ≈øecond is the multitude of witne≈ø≈øes of her ≈øinceritie. For the innocency of truth is ≈øuch, that it pre≈øently coÃÑmendeth it ≈øelfe vnto the beholder and di≈øcouereth all malicious ≈ølaunders; which when they growe vnto mo≈øt intollerable impudency, cannot yet abide the force and maie≈øty of ≈øo vn≈øpotted te≈øtimonies, again≈øt which there cannot be taken any exception. This whereas I my ≈øelfe haue founde in the peru≈øing of this worke, I could not but imparte vnto thee my minde and iudgemente. Fare-well.

Which I adde for that any Satisfactorious worke may not onely be directed for the behalfe of another as it is Satisfactorious, but if it bee deuoutely offered for the obtaining of anie good thing for our Neighbour, it is al≈øo Impetratorious, and a kinde of Praier. As if one ≈øhould Receiue, or Fa≈øt, to obtaine for his brother health, or any vertue. And this effecte of obtaining is founded in the liberality of our Sauior & promi≈øe, yt what≈øoeuer we ≈øhal aske in his name he wil graunt vnto vs.

Now of the≈øe three thinges certaine it is that the fir≈øt redoundeth onely to the good of him wc w rketh.Eccle≈ø. 16, 15 Rom. 2, 6. For all mercy ≈øhall make a place to euery man according to the merite of his workes: no pure creature hauing this priuiledge to merite for any other: that being the priuiledge of Chri≈øt alone who hauing no neede of merite him≈øelfe for the glory of his owne ≈øoule, it being endowed with all wi≈ødome grace and glory euen from the fir≈øt moment of his conception, de≈øerued grace and glory for vs al. Who therefore is compared vnto a Nur≈øe. For euery other per≈øon by his ordinary nutriment receiuing benefitte & ≈øub≈øtance for him≈øelfe alone: the nur≈øe eateth for her ≈øelfe, and for her child. But the other two may effectually be donne for others, for as a man may pray for another: ≈øo may he al≈øo ≈øatisfie for another, if both be in grace: as we haue prooued,Exod. 32, 32 Rom. 9, 3. Gen. 18, 33. & may be vnder≈øtood al≈øo by MOISES and S. PAVL, who de≈øired of God to ≈øatisfie for their peoples faulte: & by tho≈øe iu≈øt, which if they had bene found in SODOME, ≈øhoulde haue ≈øaued the wholle Citie. Yet there is here to be ob≈øerued,
that although tho≈øe which are in deadly ≈øinne be not wholly excluded from the communication of the meritts of the Church: this is onely in re≈øpect of her praiers in which they are included, and of a certaine kinde of meritte which the Diuines call DE CONGRVO of conueniency, farre inferiour to that which we ≈øpoke of, and of no certainty. But of this ≈øatisfaction by way of Iu≈øtice: they are no way partakers: becau≈øe they be deade members.

Thirdly heereof doth followe that nece≈ø≈øarily we mu≈øt admitte ≈øome workes of Supererogation,3 Workes of Supererogation. See pag. 410 which may be vnder≈øtoode of two ≈øorts. Fir≈øt, tho≈øe are called workes of Supererogation, which belong to the Euangelicall Councells: of which enough hath beene ≈øaide before. Secondly, tho≈øe are called workes of Supererogation, which although in re≈øpecte of Meritte, they be profitable to the per≈øon by which they bee wrought: yet in re≈øpect of their Satisfaction which they haue in them, were not nece≈ø≈øarie to the doers of them. They hauing not in Gods iudgement de≈øerued ≈øo much penaltie as they heere ≈øuffered: their euerla≈øting puni≈øhment fir≈øt beeing remitted; if euer they de≈øerued it: which I adde, becau≈øe of our Ble≈ø≈øed LADY who was neuer ≈øubiecte to ≈øuch de≈øerte. Such a one was fir≈øt our Ble≈ø≈øed LADY, the mo≈øt aboundant fountaine nexte vnto Chri≈øt of al Meritte and Sati≈øfaction.Col. 1, 24. Such another was Saint PAVL who as he ≈øaith him≈øelfe ≈øuffered for the wholle body of Chri≈øt. Such a one was al≈øo the holy Patriarche IOB by Gods owne iudgement and te≈øtimony approoued.Iob 42.7. Iob 6, 2. who although he confe≈ø≈øed that he had de≈øerued wrath: yet he bouldly ≈øaieth that the calamitie
which he ≈øuffered in re≈øpecte of his de≈øertes was heauier than the ≈øande of the ≈øea: Such were the holy Chri≈øtians of Hieru≈øalem whom S. PAVL ≈øaieth to haue hadde aboundance of ≈øpiritual trea≈øures:2. Cor. 8, 14. Such al≈øo no doubt were the holy Apo≈øtles and infinite Martyrs & other Saintes of God.Gen. 16, 12. And here no doubt an Hereticke like a reprobate I≈ømaelite who≈øe hands are again≈øt al, and all handes again≈øt him, who alwaies pitcheth his tenthes oppo≈øite to his Brethren: wil ≈øcoffe and taunt, vttering the wholle ≈øtoare and talent of his ≈øcurrill religion. But how ≈øhall we auoide him? for if we exaggerate our ≈øinnes, and humbly ≈øeeke to confe≈ø≈øe them: then are we ≈øuper≈øtitious, and butchers of our owne con≈øciences: if we with all humilitie1. Cor. 1, 31. glory in our Lorde who hath by his ble≈ø≈øed Pa≈ø≈øion giuen ≈øuch pretiou≈øe2. Pet. 1, 4. giftes vnto vs, that we1. Io. 3, 1. may be the ≈øonnes of God, & receiue2. Cor. 1, 22. the pledge of his ≈øpirite in our hartes, and haue himMat. 10, 20. 2. Cor. 13, 3. ≈øpeaking andPhil. 2, 13. 1. The≈ø. 2.13. working within vs, by who≈øe in≈øtinct and influenceRo. 8, 3. we may doe workes acceptable vnto God: then doe wee depre≈ø≈øe the merittes of Chri≈øts death: & are enemies vnto his grace. If we be very ≈øeuere in exacting rigorous Penances as in the Primitiue Church: than doe we tru≈øt too much in our own Satisfaction. If with the lenity & mildne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, we remitte due & nece≈ø≈øarie Satisfactions; then we v≈øurpe the office of Chri≈øt to pardon ≈øinnes.
div.q: Quo teneam nodo mutantem Protea vultus?
div.p:
Mat 11, 18.So was Saint IHON Bapti≈øt by the Iewes reprehended
for too much au≈øteritie, and our Sauiour for his kinde and liberall conuer≈øation.

But letting alone al large di≈øcour≈øes of this pointes lea≈øt we ≈øhould make a long volume: to a Catholicke, whome I intend onely heere to in≈øtructe, this which I will nowe adde, ≈øhal be a ≈øure demon≈øtration. For if one be a Martyr,An euident argument for works of Supererogation. both according to the holy Scriptures and to the wholle con≈øent of Fathers & practi≈øe of the Church, his only death is a ≈øufficient ≈øatisfaction for all his temporal puni≈øhement. Nowe if he doe not only die for iu≈øtice, but be mo≈øt barbarou≈øly Whipped, Mocked, Racked, & Mangled, and that without any re≈øpecte of ordinary humanity, as we knowe to haue beene doone in the Primitiue Church: O letNum. 23, 10. my ≈øoule die with the death of the iu≈øt: howP≈øa. 115, 15. pretiou≈øe in the ≈øight of God is the death of his Saints? our LordP≈øal. 23, 31. keepeth all the bones of them, one of them ≈øhall not peri≈øhe: what ≈øuperaboundance of Pa≈ø≈øions is heere? Now the≈øe and ≈øuch like workes: in that they were Meritorious, are rewarded in their own per≈øons with glory: but in that they are Satisfactorious:Col. 1, 24. they accompli≈øhe that which wanteth in the Pa≈ø≈øions of Chri≈øt for his body. They ≈øhall not want their corre≈øpondence of de≈øerued remi≈ø≈øion applied vnto others their fellowe members. No otherwi≈øe than when nature hauing ≈øerued the vitall members with due nouri≈øhement, afterward deriueth her liberality vnto all other partes of the body. And thus much of workes of Supererogation.

Fourthly hereof nowe is heaped an infinite ma≈ø≈øe,The Trea≈øure of Indulgences. or trea≈øure of the Satisfactions of Chri≈øt and of his Saints, that is, of the wholle my≈øticall body of Chri≈øt. which is called the trea≈øure of Indulgences. For all the
benefite of our ≈øatisfactions is fir≈øt applied to our own nece≈ø≈øities (if we doe not otherwi≈øe apply them to the good of our neighbour, which we may doe with very great Charity, although we neede them our ≈øelues) But if there be any thing in them ≈øuperfluous vnto any Saint for his owne paiments, not applied by him≈øelfe in the very doing of them for ≈øome other: than are they layed vp in the Churches Trea≈øure, to be applied as ≈øhe ≈øhall with her wi≈øedome decree. Nowe therefore out of al the≈øe infallible foundations, I gather my purpo≈øe in this manner.

An inuincible rea≈øon for Indulgences.There is a ≈øufficient trea≈øure in the Church for to recompence the wholle debte of temporall puni≈øhement, which is in all the liuely members of Chri≈øt: But ≈øuch trea≈øure may be applied vnto the≈øe members, by tho≈øe which gouerne the family of Chri≈øt: therefore may tho≈øe which gouerne this family, pardon and remitte vnto them the temporall puni≈øhment for ≈øinnes. Which rea≈øon is ≈øo manife≈øtly deduced out of that which went before, that we neede not to make any larger di≈øcour≈øe.
10 Diuer≈øe Illations out of the Premi≈ø≈øes, concerning the nature of Pardons.

1 A Pardon is not only an ab≈øolution, but al≈øo a ‚Ä¢ compen
‚Ä¢ ation for ≈øinnes.TO conclude this wholle Treati≈øe of Indulgences, we may gather out of that which is ≈øaid: Fir≈øt, that although a Pardon be principally and properly an ab≈øolution from the debte of puni≈øhement; giuen by the vertue of the KEIES: Yet is it al≈øo a kind of compen≈øation withal. For the Prelate graunting a Pardon, doth ≈øo ab≈øolue the Penitent, that he maketh out of the trea≈øure of the Chuch, an equall paimenr vnto Almighty God for the wholle debte:
paying in the heade, & in other members, that which ≈øhoulde without his ≈øacred autority haue beene paied by the partie him≈øelfe. Or thus more plainly, for the capacitie of the ≈øimpler ≈øorte: a Pardon is a mercifull relea≈øe in re≈øpecte of the Penitente: but in re≈øpecte of Gods iu≈øtice, an equall payment, made by the merits of others, applied for a recompence of the Penitent his ≈øinnes. And heerein we may ≈øee howe this ab≈øolution differeth from the Sacramental ab≈øolution in penance.Howe Pardons differ from ye Sacrament of Penance. For there, is applied onely the Merits of Chri≈øt, & not of his Saintes: whereas their merits coulde not reache vnto the taking away of the ≈øinnes them≈øelues, nor of the euerla≈øting paine due vnto the ≈øame. But here the merittes al≈øo of the Saintes in as much as they are Satisfactorious, doe take place. God hauing ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, that according to ye ≈øweet gouernment of his Church, his members doe in the cour≈øe of their iu≈øtification & deliuery from all puni≈øhements, what they are able: they being able by the concour≈øe of his Spirite nowe dwelling within them to ≈øatisfie for temporall paine. Be≈øides, in Penance the wholle euerla≈øting paine is taken away, but heere not alwaies the wholle temporall correction, but ≈øo much onely as it plea≈øeth the giuer, according to the proportion of the cau≈øe. Finally the Sacramente is an in≈øtrument of Chri≈øtes eternall Prie≈øthoode, in which he him≈øelfe remitteth ≈øinnes by the in≈øtrumentary mini≈øtery of his prie≈øt: But in Indulgences the Prelate is properly the worker, by his autority receiued from Chri≈øt: neither is it nece≈ø≈øarie that he be a Prie≈øt or Bi≈øhop, if he haue iuri≈ødiction: which may be in a Bi≈øhop elected & yet not con≈øecrated.

Secondly,2 Onely Bi≈øhoppes ca ‚Ä¢ giue Pard ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
we inferre that onely Bi≈øhoppes can giue Pardons to tho≈øe which are of theire Dioce≈ø≈øe:
and that not onely for the re≈øtrainte made by the Church: but al≈øo for the very nature and condition of Pardons. For although vnto all Prie≈øtes be ≈øaide who≈øe ≈øinnes ≈øoeuer you forgiue they ≈øhall be forgiuen: yet is this authoritie alwaies vnder≈øtood according to the nece≈ø≈øarie regiment which Chri≈øt hath ordained in his Church. And therefore a Prie≈øt cannot by his Prie≈øthood alone ab≈øolue, except he haue iuri≈ødiction al≈øo. Likewi≈øe an ordinarie Prie≈øt, although he be a Pari≈øh Prie≈øt, and haue cure of ≈øoules, cannot excommunicate: and yet that autoritie belongeth vnto the Keies of the Church. The≈øe thinges therefore doe require ≈øuch ≈øoueraigne autoritie as is in the chiefe gouernours and Prelates of the Church: and e≈øpeacialy in this pre≈øent ca≈øe: where the common trea≈øure of the familie being di≈øpen≈øed, there mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie be had the con≈øent of the ruler of the ≈øame, which is euery Bi≈øhop.

3 Bi≈øhoppes power in graunting Pardons, is iu≈øtly limited.Thirdely we may gather, that the POPE in limiting the Indulgences of Bi≈øhops, hath not doone them any iniury at all. For the Bi≈øhoppe hath not autoritie ouer the works of any which are not his ≈øubiects. And tho≈øe al≈øo being once dead belong no more to his dioce≈ø≈øe, than to another: and con≈øequently the application of their Merittes is out of his iuri≈ødiction. Wherefore his particular trea≈øure beeing ≈øo vncertaine (for it may ≈øo fall out that in his wholle Dioce≈ø≈øe there may be very fewe ≈øuperfluous ≈øatisfactions) the POPE in limiting him hath prouided for all inconueniences, lea≈øt the Bi≈øhop deceiue the people, in promi≈øing more than he may performe: which in ≈øacred matters is a pernitious thing. And moreouer, it is very probably to be thought, yt the POPE hath allowed tho≈øe Indulgences
which Bi≈øhops may giue, as out of the common Trea≈øure of the wholle Church, and ≈øo there can be no doubt of the value of them at al, nor any iniury in re≈øtraining the Bi≈øhop, who is rather holpeÃÑ thereby.

Fourthly hence appeareth the rea≈øon,4 None caÃÑ receiue Indulgence wt b ‚Ä¢ in deadlie ≈øinne. why an Indulgence cannot be receiued by him which is out of Grace. For Grace is nece≈ø≈øarie to participate ye benefit of other mens Satisfactions. And the Indulgence giueth me onlie ≈øo much as my owne Satisfaction could doe: but my Satisfaction were nothing doone out of Gods fauour: therefore can the Indulgence heere auaile me nothing.

Fifthly we may nowe vnder≈øtand what difference there is betweene the Satisfaction of others applied by the Church: and by one man vnto another.5 He wc ≈øati≈øfieth for an other doth not graunt Indulgence For he which applieth his own Satisfaction to another, cannot ≈øurely knowe whether him≈øelfe be in Grace, and con≈øequently whether his Satisfaction be accepted of God: But the≈øe Satisfactions applied in Indulgences are mo≈øt certaine. Be≈øides: another man applying his Satisfaction for my reliefe, doth not ab≈øolue me from my debte of Satisfaction, but only payeth for me. Wherefore I am ≈øtill bound to fulfil my Penance, that beeing a meere per≈øonall worke to bee vndertaken by my ≈øelfe: But the contrary is in Indulgences as hath beene declared before. La≈øt of al, after the worke is pa≈øt, we cannot apply the Satisfaction of it vnto our neighbour: but it either helpeth our ≈øelues, or if it were not nece≈ø≈øary for our ≈øelues, it goeth into the common trea≈øure: But the Church applieth the Satisfactions of workes which are pa≈øt to our reliefe in Indulgence.

Sixthly, he which receiueth an Indulgence,6 Publicke nance enioined, is not alway takeÃÑ away by Pardon. is bound notwith≈øtanding to fulfill all Penances which
are publickely enioined him. For indulgences onely take place in the court of Con≈øcience, and betweene God and vs: vnle≈ø≈øe it be otherwi≈øe expre≈ø≈øed. And tho≈øe Penances are to Satisfie the worlde ≈øcandalized by our faultes, and to be a warning for others from committing the like.

7 No bla≈øphemie in ≈øaying that by Pardon, recompence is made to God.Seauenthly it is no bla≈øphemy to ≈øay that in Pardons is made an equal recompence for paines of ≈øinnes vnto Gods Iu≈øtice. For it is Chri≈øt which paieth, and maketh this recompeÃÑce out of the merits of his whole body, that is, his owne, and his Saints merits. For he hath entered into ≈øo ≈øtraite a ≈øociety with his members, that they accompli≈øhe that which wanteth of his Pa≈ø≈øions in their fle≈øh. But it is no bla≈øphemy to ≈øay that Chri≈øts merites make an equal recompence for ≈øinnes.
11 Of Pardons for the Deade.

FInally, wee hence inferre that Pardons may bee graunted vnto the Deade, who in the vnitie of CHRISTES body, haue departed this life: and that in as infallible a manner (if the cau≈øe bee ≈øufficient) as vnto tho≈øe which are aliue: yet not by waye of ab≈øolution, but by waye of Suffrage, which we will forthwith expounde. For it is to be vnder≈øtoode:See pag. 219 Three kind of Suffrages for ye deade. yt the ≈øoules departed out of this worlde, & in Purgatorie ≈øuffering the cha≈øti≈øement of God: may, as aboue hath bin ≈øhewed out of S. AVGVSTINE, be holpen by tho≈øe which are aliue, three waies. Fir≈øt, by ye holy Sacrifice of the MASSE: which is vndoubtedly propitiatory for the quicke and the dead. Secondly, by the praiers of the Church, and of other deuoute Chri≈øtians. Thirdly by Almes, or any other Penall worke doone for them. And concerning the fir≈øt: becau≈øe
it is not our owne worke, but the very worke of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe: we will not heere ≈øpeake thereof. The ≈øecond is founded as we ≈øaide before, in the meere liberality of Chri≈øt, without any certaine promi≈øe. For although God infalliblely doth heare and graunt the Petition of one which is in grace, when he praieth for him≈øelfe,D. Thom. 2.2. quae≈øt. 83. artic. 15. and for nece≈ø≈øary things vnto ≈øaluation, & with humility and per≈øeuerance: yet when he praieth for another, either aliue or dead, there is no ≈øuch certainty and infallibility of obtaining. Becau≈øe we know not, whether, or howe farre God accepteth our praier, nor the di≈øpo≈øition of the other. The like is to be ≈øaid of that imperfecte kinde of Merit, which is called DE CONGRVO of Congruity or Conueniency: For oftentimes one which is in grace meriteth for another man either aliue or dead, many good thinges: yet becau≈øe herein is no certaine Lawe or promi≈øe of God, or rea≈øon of Iu≈øtice betweeene him and vs: as there is in the other merit of condignity, which wee ≈øpake of before: there is no certainty but all lefte to the ≈øecret di≈øpo≈øition of God. But the third thing, which is to offer for them which are dead in Chri≈øt either Almes, or Fa≈øting, or any other work of Satisfaction, yea, & Praier, in as much as it is Satisfactorious, becau≈øe of the labour thereof: hath an infallible effecte, euen of iu≈øtice for to ≈øatisfie for their paines. Yet ≈øo that the offerer be in grace. The rea≈øon of this, is, that which we touched before, for that they be of the Communion of Chri≈øtes my≈øticall body: and in great neede of helpe: and therefore doe receiue the influence from the heade, as other members doe. And as there is an equality of Iu≈øtice in the ≈øatisfaction of one iu≈øt man offered for another beeing aliue: ≈øo al≈øo is there the
≈øame kind of iu≈øtice, in the ≈øame ≈øatisfactioÃÑ, offered for the dead.Prayer is two waies profitable vnto the Deade. Wherefore it is very profitable for him which praieth for the dead, not only to offer his praier to obtaine mercie for him: but al≈øo to offer vnto God that very labour of praying for him. For in this re≈øpecte it is ≈øatisfactorious, & hath an infallible effecte for him: in the other re≈øpecte it is impetratorious, and hath no certaine promi≈øed mea≈øure of benefite, but only according to Gods meere liberality, the deuotion of the partie which praieth, and the e≈øtate of the party decea≈ø≈øed con≈øidered. Yet doe I not doubt but that alwaies ≈øomething is al≈øo obtained, when the ≈øatisfaction is auaileable. For it belongeth to Gods merciful liberality to be≈øtowe where we by, his gratious permi≈ø≈øion & promi≈øe doe be≈øtow: ≈øo that it is very conuenient to thinke that if in ≈øuch praier the ≈øatisfaction be ≈øufficiently deriued to the deade by our application: God al≈øo by hearing the ≈øame Praier doth liberally graunt our reque≈øt in part, and adde ≈øomewhat to the value of our ≈ømall recompence which we make for our Brother. Yet as the quantity is vncertaine ≈øo may it be much more, the deuotioÃÑ of the praier being feruent, than that wc proceedeth from the certaine limited fruit of the ≈øatisfaction.
The≈øe helpes therfore which we may afforde vnto ye ≈øoules departed: are called the Suffrages of ye Deade.

Now eueÃÑ as in tho≈øe which are aliue, by the Indulgences of the Church, recompence is made for that teÃÑ porall puni≈øhment which they a ‚Ä¢ e de≈øerued: ≈øo al≈øo may the ≈øame Indulgences take away the debtes of tho≈øe which are departed, and that as infallibly, as they are profitable to tho≈øe which are in this worlde.

For this is the wholle cour≈øe of an Indulgence in this life. PETER oweth vnto Almightie God great
Penance: and becau≈øe men which are aliue may applye their ≈øatisfactions for PETERS reliefe: therefore may the POPE out of the Trea≈øure of the wholle Church yeelde vnto PETER conuenient reliefe: of which infallibly PETER ≈øhall be partaker if he be in grace: and a recompence of iu≈øtice is made vnto God for PETERS debte. Euen ≈øo is it in the deade: who for that they may be partakers of common Suffrages of the Church: may by Indulgences receiue a perfect ≈øupply of that which by the ≈øuffrages they may receiue.

This doe the Diuines call,Per moduÃÑ Suffragij. and it is ≈øo al≈øo called in the ordinary Pardons, By way of Suffrage: that is, not as ≈øome doe mi≈ø≈øe vnder≈øtand it: as if the meaning of ≈øuch a Pardon were, if they can obtaine it of God, they ≈øhall deliuer a Soule out of Purgatory: for then the Pardon could not be of certaine force for the dead: But the ≈øen≈øe is: they ≈øhall deliuer a Soule out of Purgatory: euen as if they had donne ≈øo much of ordinary Suffrages for them, as were ≈øufficient for the wholle effect of the Indulgence. This ≈øhall be more cleere if we con≈øider, the cau≈øe of this maner of ≈øpeach, which was this. To tho≈øe which liue in this world: Indulgences are not onely recompences made to God for our debte: but al≈øo a proper ab≈øolution: The POPE ab≈øoluing vs, and paying that which wee owe out of the Trea≈øure. Nowe the POPE hauing no autoritie or iuri≈ødiction ouer the deade, he cannot ab≈øolue them: yet as he may and all other Chri≈øtians may by common Suffrages yeelde them conuenient helpe: ≈øo may he ≈øupply ≈øuch helpe by applying out of the Trea≈øure, that which may be auaileable vnto them.
